question: 示す
sourceMnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>indicate</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to indicate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to show</vocabulary>. This is used in contexts like "a study shows that learning Japanese is fun" and "I demonstrated my willingness to learn kanji".
sourceReadingMnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Studies seem <vocabulary>to indicate</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to show</vocabulary> that <reading>shee</reading>p <reading>me</reading>n (<ja>しめ</ja>) are better than regular men in every way. The sheep/man combo is a powerful thing. Or so studies indicate.
